9CD6FB85B34C4AB1A7CA38019602843D.description: Develop and/or revise personal and career goals based on the work placement experience.

1DE11EB39D8E41F78C68E66EC57EDAE5.description: Prepare a letter, note, card or other communication for the work placement employer, expressing appreciation.

2C66C0C732CD4A958EB7CFE168E1D7AC.description: Update personal career documentation (e.g., resume, portfolio) following the work placement.

278E1BF83C624AD5A4D3071D43E811DD.description: Reflect on the attainment of personal and learning goals.

416169965B7B4739B8513237EFF18196.description: Showcase one’s skills and abilities demonstrated during the work placement using artifacts, evidence of skill development and personal reflections on aspects of the work experience such as: hours worked; responsibilities and tasks performed; the importance of attitude towards work and taking responsibility for what needs to be done; details about the entry level wage, salary scales and earning potential; worker rights and responsibilities and the role of the union, if applicable; ownership structure (e.g., corporation, franchise, sole proprietorship, partnership); and, opportunities for advancement at the workplace and elsewhere in the industry.

DCB822E2DC724DAEA2FC66550D90877E.description: Relate one’s work placement experience to personal and career goals

12DC5D56075B4EBBACC8962D7E796ECD.description: Document knowledge and awareness of employment standards, safety, workplace ethics, rights and responsibilities, occupational health and safety, and networking observed during the work placement.

1FBD37936FCB4041B1B339295D961A70.description: Document one’s experience using electronic and other tools (e.g., vlogs, blogs, log sheets, reflective journals) to summarize and reflect upon items such as: hours of work including breaks; • responsibilities and tasks performed; interactions with the employer, staff, customers and others; company or organization’s ‘raison d’être;’ and, skills developed and demonstrated during the work placement that enhance one’s employability.

AB52708BA36E4150A5A369DD2064E6C3.description: Apply relevant skills and abilities during the work placement experience.

3B6F8113751C43DA8FA0305021DBF848.description: Participate in a work placement experience.

3A1BABE7AB4C4D6AA85CDA1FF36A5185.description: Reflect upon one’s performance during the interview

1CE0E55C38ED410A8EC7178995C26524.description: Participate in an interview with the employer prior to beginning the work placement.

CA8EDEE0C8534F549B3516A5F57C0794.description: Develop a list of questions that could potentially be asked by the employer/work placement in an interview situation as well as answers to the questions

268F78D1D9F745CCB84CB029964E7456.description: Brainstorm a list of questions to ask the employer before beginning the work placement; these may include: What is my schedule of work hours? Who is my supervisor? What should I wear? When will I be provided with safety training? What potential hazards might I encounter in the work placement? Where do I find fire extinguishers, first aid kits and emergency assistance? What type of safety gear am I expected to wear? Is it provided? What should I do if I get injured or have an accident in the workplace? How can I contact my health and safety committee or representative? Are there any health and safety procedures I should follow? Who is the first aid person? Where are safety notices posted? What should I do in case of a fire or emergency?

8ED44A1037344C00BECCC98B69743F5B.description: Compile an employer information package that includes documents needed for the work placement (e.g., personal career documentation such as a resume or portfolio, permission forms, logs, self- and employer evaluation forms).

0521DC18DBE6472AB4CD385F38BD70E0.description: Develop a procedural guide for the work placement that includes items such as: transportation to and from the work placement; hours of work; guidelines for absence and tardiness; dress code; job description; and, conflict resolution

C02EEC0B99904ECABEEB7E2587BEC275.description: In collaboration with all partners, develop personal and learning goals for the work placement

F3FF8499C1624E33B3E1CD405DFDEEAB.description: Research the business/organization to become familiar with its operations

0C3E430C675643379228B92F506DF405.description: Explain the roles and responsibilities of each partner (e.g., student, parent, teacher or other school staff, employer) involved in the work placement.

96F1505571EB41CE9B49E7BE1502352A.description: Describe and reflect on the three basic rights that all workers have under Part III – Occupational Health and Safety in The Saskatchewan Employment Act, 2019: the right to know – the hazards at work and how to control them; the right to participate – in finding and controlling workplace hazards; and, the right to refuse – work that you believe is unusually dangerous.

1B42077487B54F10897BC3A780EAEE3D.description: Reflect on personal contributions to, and personal growth resulting from, developing and implementing the campaign.

6BD6555C4FBF44688C6738679ACC553E.description: Reflect on the successes and challenges of the campaign.

F6D183D2AAB346539A0EC592DC905231.description: Collaborate with team members to conduct research and to develop a public awareness campaign.

F6944AC34A184F73ABEADB1C24A7B46D.description: Identify a community safety concern (e.g., proper installation and use of car seats, sun safety, snowmobile safety, pedestrian crossing safety, texting and driving, vehicle or home emergency kits, fire extinguishers in the home).

B346347D8C3045F3942826C8E1F03B23.description: Describe the characteristics (e.g., clearly defined goal(s) or outcomes, a well-defined target audience, specific actions requested of the target audience, plans for measuring success) of a successful awareness campaign or program

8A5FFDAFCFE54170BE839354CA191CB1.description: Discuss the purpose of a public awareness campaign.

4F55D563380840A7BD5B2E2997AF0C7F.description: Create a public awareness campaign that addresses a community safety concern.

388C8ECCD14143BFA5942B558160E5CE.description: Examine strategies and ways that individuals who are lost can make it easier for searchers to find them.

123521E2292C4F8CB1148DD56E861926.description: Create a lost person profile for self.

3602F199F0B54CCCB37FECACD6D2C772.description: Describe the importance, components (i.e., physical abilities, mental condition, experience, personality, behaviour statistics) and application of a lost subject profile.

B62F0C438B7C46EC8D8A32C17F92BDDA.description: Research facts about lost person behaviour pertaining to factors such as age (e.g., toddler, child, teenager, adult), mental conditions (e.g., suffering from dementia or mental illness) and reason for being outdoors (e.g., hiker, hunter, nature photographer).

62660E9DC47A4715B1F6684229090A82.description: Describe scenarios when an individual may be considered lost (e.g., a small child wanders away from a farmyard; a hunter does not return home at the anticipated time; a lone skier on a remote hill breaks a leg in a fall and cannot move).

A5067D1DC33E460BAD46C2E465C6B0CE.description: Examine the relationship between an understanding of lost person behaviour and successful search and rescue efforts.

F41B768A2C8C48C78851BAA7F84E76F6.description: Describe the purpose and process of an After Action Review (AAR).

9038D00E96194F77BAEF8CF564873E2B.description: Discuss typical procedures for call-out and check-in associated with a SAR mission.

A5CB42EDDE7245689798C1D11337DA2A.description: Explain protocols that are required to conduct a SAR mission on First Nations land or for a First Nations individual.

9E4B2A70CF2543DEAE06019DCB3CE814.description: Examine the contributions (e.g., knowledge of the land, community, people and language) that First Nations Knowledge Keepers can make to a SAR mission on First Nations land or for a First Nation’s individual.

068D9CACE71A44A5BED0FB64D5A9FD16.description: Demonstrate proper procedures for radio communication for a SAR mission.

81F2F58644A147C6AFECAB1F799B6086.description: Analyze codes for radio communication that are unique to SAR in Saskatchewan.

EA898BA7CEC345D4864003B26B55B266.description: Identify practical steps for maintaining field health and hygiene for SAR missions of varying durations and in a variety of locations

0AE86DF5221E4E07AB678AD21A8EA0B9.description: Explain the importance of field health and hygiene while on a SAR mission.

135F3D7877494958B68CEAE51580C230.description: Practise packing a 24-hour kit and equipment in a backpack for SAR mission.

AB995419B0554FA8A907CB5B0D97D13A.description: Identify the items typically found in a 24-hour SAR kit.

799B8BED40104B5596A0EEEC690ADEB9.description: Analyze differences in supplies, clothing and equipment required for SAR missions in various locations (e.g., northern, rural, urban, remote) and at various times of the year in Saskatchewan.

57F07086FF494A88A83B6F44E7E0EB98.description: Demonstrate correct operation of equipment such as a GPS or compass commonly used by searchers.

D47F79345B2043B5BA12E9362702139A.description: Identify SAR technology tools (e.g., GPS, Family Radio Systems, Personal Location Beacons, Night Vision Goggles).

8A6A60BEB22244759F8DADF3A3AF8704.description: Examine the four phases of a search and rescue (SAR) mission according to the SAME acronym: Search – searching for and finding the subject(s); Access – reaching the subject(s); Medical aid – providing as needed; and, Evacuate – moving the subject(s).

2AC7EF7B8F73407EAD346ABFEA372E1D.description: Analyze elements of a search and rescue mission.

594271E0AB0641BAA5B2D2352A441856.description: Examine the importance and use of drill among the various areas of emergency services.

D77EC625062E4936ABAEF260A536F56B.description: Research the use of uniform and dress, including ceremonial attire, associated with various areas of emergency services.

0804D7AFC24448DB8A06103B7A7D01C9.description: Develop and implement a plan for developing and demonstrating additional professional skills required for a successful career in emergency services.

13110CECE47740D58FE6C7FCC5F04172.description: Assess personal attainment of the professional skills required for a successful career in emergency services.

A8692859CDEB4E859E81B4AAF42A4AAD.description: Justify the personal and professional importance of deportment for those who work in emergency services.

17A97130D73B46EDA41224E1F5473BE1.description: Reflect on good deportment for a student or community member.

975E694DF6D04A749A4734D30C73CB4F.description: Summarize professional skills (e.g., respect for all individuals, groups and people; punctuality; integrity; ability to contribute positively to a team with diverse members; responsible use of social media) that contribute to good deportment.

EE1651D24235450F8BC903034B85A61B.description: Explain deportment as it relates to the professionalism of emergency services personnel.

4B2DB7C8C6634D31B6B2E82FDD113320.description: Assess the purpose and importance of drill and deportment in all areas of emergency services.

0D2851773B414DAFBE3FBD8F43A4BBA4.description: Demonstrate additional firefighting skills such as rescue tactics, making a mayday call and ice management.

0D5D6131AE7148F7A0974C17357DF925.description: As part of a team, select and deploy appropriate hoses, nozzles and appliances for fire suppression during mock firefighting situations.

597326A943C44164966B2140CDFA8605.description: Identify appropriate fire suppression evolutions in various fire scenarios.

13066837597E4A0DAD347938FBF56A5C.description: Select and use appropriate hand and small tools to complete firefighting support tasks.

71ED4D177BF34D9F81959A16AF724889.description: Select and effectively use PPE that is appropriate for controlled hazardous situations and environments encountered during scenarios staged by the local fire department.

BCDA3539D4334550BA95637A11259F67.description: Demonstrate practical firefighting skills during mock firefighting and other scenarios facilitated and supported by the local fire department.

99535F720A2A4088A6E264C0B4EB603A.description: Assess the role that commercial and other pilots can play in detecting and reporting WUI fires.

EDF7CF329D4048F0ABBB702D41844798.description: Examine factors (e.g., wind, topography, environmental factors such as drought) that contribute to WUI fire development.

0BB231CCF6854058BB83396612E9B3AF.description: Assess firefighting challenges commonly presented by wildland fires and WUI fires and the possible tactics for fighting them.

47ABE60CF44B4856AD12A1856075DCB9.description: Research statistics related to the occurrence of wildland and WUI fires in Saskatchewan and Canada, the cost of fighting these fires and who pays for the firefighting services.

B1473FC74E2F486D98F0ECA0C5DFFCC1.description: Identify wildland fuels common to the local area and other regions in Saskatchewan.

27B3519F5E0947CD94DBD661AD7B37DD.description: Investigate fire-burning properties of a variety of wildland fuels such as grass, leaves, large trees, stumps and slash.

C93BE1EC85714D689AA01F37E6CEBE24.description: Differentiate between wildland fuels (e.g., vegetation such as grass and large trees) and built fuels (e.g., human development such as buildings).

7402AB4F8A574C2C940BDDCC4F3E07A8.description: Describe what is meant by the wildland-urban interface (WUI).

37741F0D5EF8402F88E19FC2E24EDA4A.description: Examine wildland and wildland-urban interface firefighting.

B9EFE24751EC4F83AFB7C296A608CAF7.description: Investigate the role and function of an incident safety officer at the incident scene.

CF93C6B86F0A47DAA9D3BE987DD5D3CF.description: Assess the importance of fireground awareness, including the initial observation of a firefighting scene, for the safety of self and others.

68116EDD7F8E4441BD8B4537526E63EF.description: Explore proper techniques for carrying or dragging an injured person to safety.

7904E180BC2747E38BDB9A8476C68540.description: Investigate firefighter responses to a mayday call.

ABC99204E33A4D4E80D055029956A65B.description: Describe the meaning of a mayday call in a firefighting situation.

7608E579BDA54B679ADAAA1FA7F35554.description: Discuss the importance of the buddy system for firefighting.

83E8E6AB39024333B7BBBEE70F16857A.description: Reflect on ways (e.g., wearing a safety vest for greater visibility, choosing clothing appropriate for weather conditions, selecting the proper PPE) to work safely as a firefighter.

D325A3DF117049928E9776BB911B9284.description: Examine fire ground safety practices and procedures.

E093FEB5A50240768F6FF61A255594DF.description: Plan the deployment of a fire attack strategy that includes identification of command and suppression functions of all officers and firefighters involved for various given scenarios.

46FAF8FEFE7A40A8A38BFD5A24641255.description: Determine the proper procedure for carrying and rolling a fire hose and for connecting fire hose couplings.

C5B076001C0541EDB5B3759FC9D2499A.description: Research factors for selecting, placing and handling handlines and master stream appliances for applying water to a fire.

97705E03F659441AAC911E33FAF35D25.description: Discuss factors that help firefighters determine the best way (e.g., cutting a hole, going through an opening such as a door or window) to conduct a forcible entry.

293F8914DD8F46CDA39A5F11D356D230.description: Examine situations when forcible entry of a building may be justified.

DDCCB519A04B4667B0E718758DF9ACA0.description: Discuss the importance of firefighters’ awareness of the contents and organization of a fire truck.

BCBEC24C438B4017A5C79FCE901C495C.description: Examine firefighting uses for items commonly found on a fire truck.

3093EA556EE04D2DB45D8DFC212D658F.description: Justify the selection and use of specific hand tools to ensure effective extinguishments and fighter safety for a variety of given scenarios.

C119E8ECD1C44139A3CA87E645937257.description: Demonstrate proper usage of hand tools (e.g., axes, shovels, fire rakes) for fire-fighting support tasks.

B4960AE0FA8141738CEEBCD131A8F2C4.description: Describe practical firefighting applications for each type of knot.

186D1F0327AB4A3AA71FC57AC3548DCA.description: Demonstrate the correct procedure for tying each type of knot.

D24D83AF57CE4442BADD6DA78C228A92.description: Identify seven basic knots (i.e., overhand safety, clove hitch, half hitch, bowline, figure 8 on a bight, becket, water) commonly used by firefighters.

89B221D4D08747EEB3C6ADFAA7280CD7.description: Explain circumstances for using a variety of laddering techniques.

4F39E2D3C7D045149529DEBD09C0297F.description: Describe characteristics of, and common uses for, various types of ladders used in firefighting

255489CD01334831937FB82B734841B9.description: Investigate fire apparatuses, equipment and tactics commonly used by firefighters.

0FDCDBF7209149FCAB70CBFD74B085D9.description: Identify ventilation techniques that could potentially aid in fire control for a variety of scenarios.

E84686998FD54446B2BAC2070487F68E.description: Research the B-SAHF indicators (i.e., Building, Smoke and Air track, Heat, Flame) of fire behaviour that help firefighters locate a fire and respond appropriately.

AD8A9C1A07E34866842A784176919D01.description: Differentiate between flashover and backdraft, including the methods for preventing and managing.

7715BF821EEF4F48A1238C19DEBCB10E.description: Assess the availability and distribution of water (e.g., via water hydrants or tanker trucks) in the community and surrounding area for the purpose of firefighting.

824F08D9BBF546A9A732433E216CF7C1.description: Describe the information contained within a pre-incident plan that assists firefighters in determining appropriate firefighting attack techniques on the scene of a building/structure fire within the community.

60764920F3774C338807D1EE87CB17BD.description: Identify factors (e.g., characteristics of fuel involved and ventilation) that impact the speed of fire development

9383C4E9A4D743648F7128F174E7404C.description: Discuss the relationship between fuel type and the quantity/type of extinguishing agents available.

CE0E4B442E334A31BC79768ED3B2C58C.description: Research deployment techniques used for a variety of extinguishing agents.

A078EA3B37F14BDA91C706F68F0A7A8B.description: Examine the relationship between fire behaviour and the selection and use of fire suppression techniques.

D38BD85B5F2C4E11A451553F6D1AC936.description: Identify the fire safety officer for the local community.

BBB99A7D8CEB45EE8A7F77001FE2B87B.description: Examine the role of a fire safety officer as it relates to pre-incident planning.

98F713BAC43443BF890E33F4C484821D.description: Investigate processes for recording, storing and sharing pre-incident plans within the community.

3FBCB3DC8106401082A855FD7224E96A.description: Develop a pre-incident plan for a building/structure (e.g., home, school) within the community.

C54751D4D27F478F967CEF0276FBAEC5.description: Identify muster points within the community

4D2921827FC740E9B476A021E55FEBD4.description: Assess the importance of muster points.

49F11A2770F14C5C96721A494DC888FC.description: Research the types of information (e.g., building characteristics including a floor plan and building materials, occupancy, protective features such as a sprinkler system, hazards, location, water sources) contained within a prefire planning document or report.

1DF3AB94EB8D4E5790926EA2021205FB.description: Discuss the importance of pre-incident planning for individuals, businesses and the community.

17E4CD88B06B416E9E6FFD9662A90285.description: Describe pre-incident planning as it relates to firefighting.

BD2550C7EE9B4F71A88DFD7FF0DCB5F7.description: Assess the importance of preincident planning for individuals, families, businesses and the local community.

DF9B50FA37994076B618808253A8E2E2.description: Justify the selection of PPE appropriate for a variety of firefighting scenarios.

35F082BE5CFD4727A591D12688DD9076.description: Practise donning and doffing PPE in a variety of circumstances including darkness

2BFE3E5861EC41B893FADD59669B77F8.description: Assess problems (e.g., restricted visibility, weight, heat tolerance) associated with a variety of firefighting PPE and clothing.

EE4D8D2393C843B1B41765648599798A.description: Examine characteristics and features of firefighting PPE and clothing that make them effective.

758208365D4D46788963B77FF086C4A1.description: Describe when, where and how specific pieces of firefighting PPE and clothing could be used.

9D25E67B116541F7ADBE6A8D5E641826.description: Investigate the types of firefighting PPE and clothing (e.g., gloves, boots, undergarments, helmets, face shields, goggles, respirators, gas masks).

93613D9E5C1A46A7BF17E7F50F4782C9.description: Identify hazards (e.g., excessive heat, smoke, dust, fumes) commonly faced by firefighters

C773454403B747F2ACABF62C72CB85BD.description: Assess the use of personal protective equipment and clothing in firefighting.

5EC0B8F3AEA7484BBC72B964BCAA39EE.description: Personal Protective Equipment and Clothing for Firefighting (Optional)

4AEB7FCF30644327BC64DFF6501D796E.description: Strategize ways to cope with an incident response that does not proceed or go as personally anticipated.

41BBC88409CB4886A5A3FADFA13AB4D2.description: Assess factors (e.g., clear, concise and timely communication; cooperation among individuals and responding agencies) that contribute to a safe, efficient and effective incident response.

BDFFE9A166384E0BA98468EEFA4FE6AB.description: Reflect on personal conduct expected of all individuals responding to an incident.

FF855E66A8CA433CBD81FD902B0D5047.description: Examine the purpose and content of an initial incident briefing.

DBC1325F0C9A45039CAFF56D1DDB18C6.description: Research the purpose of a check-in process associated with an incident.

723624CD15CD404C97BA3E89F210D823.description: Identify and explain standard ICS symbols on an incident map

5B3DF02E53B74F5BA74DC48ACA18DA89.description: Investigate the purpose and examples of an incident map.

982AF2A35A8945859E5B1AAFB9578529.description: Analyze a variety of fictitious scenarios to justify: the need for, and location of, an ICP; the need for a staging area and the items that should be housed in it; and, other types of facilities that are required to support the incident response.

616E79E2527D419195447BB5E7B1C31E.description: Research other types of facilities (e.g., helibase, helispot, camp) that might be required for an incident response.

A2F330D480E1432E9A3C44871B496B18.description: Examine the types of item(s) that might be housed in a staging area.

7CE57C7126FC4BFCB1CC9E6B325EBA92.description: Explain the purpose of a staging area.

D812634939B14EE698331F49461A77D6.description: Relate the operational period to the measurable objectives outlined in an IAP.

EA986D53339B468BAE40E70D312F3D1F.description: Compare the purpose of an IAP with the purpose of an incident briefing form (ICS 201).

6497D94273CC4BE2941050B1E722BE99.description: Investigate the purpose and components of an Incident Command System (ICS) 204 form also known as the incident action plan (IAP).

3C4FC2BE7AB1464EBC4B68E1E75EE48B.description: Discuss factors (e.g., needs of the incident, length of time the ICP will be required, accessibility, space) that help determine the need for, and location of, an ICP.

A14987E94AAD4B04ACB609019705D219.description: Describe the purpose of an Incident Command Post (ICP).

82CAB23E040D499A8F507CD5CF5D4D35.description: Assess common features of an incident response.

8285BB666BFB4870B8705DAB1062EA28.description: Examine the interrelatedness among the five major components of ICS as represented by an ICS organization chart.

6D6DB18140A14C58A80BFA3DF4BA8D7F.description: Research the roles and functions associated with each major component.

C41E753EBF2A48CBA9236DBC149215B6.description: Investigate the five major components (i.e., command, operations, planning, logistics, finance/administration) within the ICS.

9CF16997B7CB46AABAF69ED543D1B3EB.description: Research the basic features of an Incident Command System (ICS), including: standardization (i.e., terminology); command (i.e., establishment and transfer of command; chain of command and unity of command; unified command); planning/organization structure (i.e., management by objectives, incident action plan, modular organization, manageable span of control); facilities and resources (i.e., comprehensive resource management, incident locations and facilities); communications/information management (i.e., integrated communications, information and intelligent management); and, professionalism (i.e., accountability, dispatch/deployment).

72AD939E0D424EC38CEAB3ED8F894F6D.description: Examine features and the basic structure of the Incident Command System.

AB07B27E36EB49DA97BBED36D6295CA8.description: Identify credible Saskatchewan and Canadian sources that offer supports for emergency services personnel experiencing psychological health challenges and for their family members.

992B4A9CD72D441581817FC9E3AE5E16.description: Discuss characteristics (e.g., registered, licensed, evidence-based) of a credible source for psychological support.

A429D2D57DDD4F6393327A95D6363C84.description: Research ways in which others (e.g., family, co-workers, friends) can support emergency services personnel facing psychological health challenges.

EBA47DD71ECB4357A05DDBE2D5AD9812.description: Investigate self-care strategies (e.g., writing in a journal, talking to others such as family and co-workers about feelings and experiences, practising breathing and relaxation techniques, maintaining a healthy diet, getting adequate sleep and exercise) that support mental health and well-being of emergency services personnel.

47F7D51F0698426DA7CED2C04D404710.description: Assess the purpose of, and steps associated with, the Critical Incident Stress Debriefing process as a traumatic intervention tool commonly used among emergency services workers.

6DD8F946F7F24DAC99F8C8388D6F7203.description: Discuss the impact of psychological health challenges faced by emergency services personnel on self and others (e.g., family, co-workers, friends).

583EE48264334AB8BDE91223BAF57EFF.description: Research statistics related to suicidal ideation, plans and attempts among emergency services personnel in Canada.

0B1F1E61043A4E9FB243FDE4A0CFD7A2.description: Describe the personal feelings, symptoms and behaviours commonly associated with various psychological health challenges.

A01AB963E1CD4A39ACA1209E45FE2278.description: Examine statistics related to the prevalence of psychological health challenges among emergency services personnel in Canada.

96643240F35A4F3A927D1006E8C1391D.description: Identify mental health challenges such as Post Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD), major depressive disorder, general anxiety disorder, social anxiety disorder, panic disorder and alcohol use disorder commonly experienced by emergency services personnel.

9E6F1C72DE9643E3AC82BB002270DED3.description: Research sources of stress (e.g., traumatic events, shift work, separation from family, public disrespect) commonly experienced by emergency services personnel.

D39E7CF6C3C24D30A3CF888085BCF382.description: Discuss the correlation between personal psychological preparedness and the ability to respond effectively in an emergency.

A7EEF9243796476DB4D3EDECEF9E172D.description: Examine the state of psychological health and well-being among emergency services personnel in Canada.

4ADD927EF9CE406CB4AA95FF30FAF0D9.description: Research employer responsibilities pertaining to PPE (e.g., training employees on the usage, limitations, care, maintenance, proper disposal) in Saskatchewan.

9F25CB905AE641D19E57893F6D847CCE.description: Identify types of PPE worn by various emergency services personnel.

EE090EE62F354EDE8E610CE48FEAEE2F.description: Discuss the need for, and importance of, proper-fitting PPE and clothing

7A0B4A2F325042E0866DA2DCB515A56C.description: Describe the purpose of Personal Protective Equipment (PPE)

9A28E94734C3407E9EE98FDDDEBF7DE5.description: Assess statistics related to workplace injuries for emergency services personnel in Saskatchewan and Canada.

2BF3811F45934149AC079217046B636A.description: Describe employers’ and employees’ rights and responsibilities pertaining to workplace hazards and how they can work together to prevent workplace hazards

537EF6C5CE3D459AAC69F37584A59E57.description: Categorize examples of potential hazards that emergency services personnel may encounter.

9D66C77FB36C42E0B57BB950CBDA9B65.description: Differentiate among the four Occupational Health and Safety hazard categories physical (e.g., heavy lifting, repetitive motion, slipping/tripping, working at heights, working alone, cuts, burns); chemical (e.g., chemicals, fumes, vapours, gases); biological (e.g., viruses, fungi, bacteria, mold; bodily fluids; sewage; animal/pet waste; influenza); and, psychological (e.g., harassment and bullying, stress, fatigue, shift work).
